message: Started workflow: Add visual verification integration: connect to visual-verification-service for AI-powered UAT testing with hybrid specific checks and open-ended evaluation, create test case templates, and update workflow to support visual UAT

details.reason: New feature addition, no existing roadmap items apply

details.notes: Asked 7 clarifying questions with recommendations and alternatives. User confirmed: single Render deployment, separate tests/visual/ dir (no redundant files), configurable style guide path in yaml, mandatory functional + mobile checks, bias toward immediate fixing, auto-run at visual_regression_test step, quick/full evaluation modes.
Created docs/plan.md with implementation plan covering: visual verification client, workflow settings, test template, CLI commands, engine integration. Decision: Use Claude Code for implementation.
Created docs/risk_analysis.md covering: service dependency, API costs, false positives, style guide drift, mobile accuracy, test file management, security, rollback plan.
Created tests/test_cases.md with 20 test cases: 8 unit tests, 7 integration tests, 4 CLI tests, 3 E2E tests. Includes mock definitions and 80% coverage requirement.

Implemented visual verification integration: visual_verification.py client, CLI commands (visual-verify, visual-template), workflow settings, documentation. Tested against live service - both desktop and mobile viewports working.

Updated CLI with --provider and --model flags.

message: Started workflow: Add function calling support to OpenRouter provider for interactive repo context

details.notes: Reviewed ROADMAP.md - this feature is new but aligns with CORE-012 (streaming) and extends OpenRouter provider capabilities. No existing roadmap item covers function calling for interactive context.

Discussed 4 questions with user. Final decisions: (1) Tools: read_file, list_files, search_code - no run_command; (2) Soft warning limits only - 2MB files, 50 calls, no total cap; (3) Fallback to context injection for models without function calling; (4) New execute_with_tools() method with auto-detection in execute()

Created docs/plan.md with 5-phase implementation: (1) Tool definitions, (2) Function calling loop, (3) Model detection, (4) Context injection fallback, (5) Testing. Includes file changes summary and success criteria.

Created docs/risk_analysis.md covering 6 risks: path traversal (R1), large files (R2), infinite loops (R3), API costs (R4), backwards compat (R5), model compat (R6). All LOW-MEDIUM severity with clear mitigations. Recommendation: proceed with emphasis on path validation and testing.

Created tests/test_cases.md with 35+ test cases covering: tool definitions (3), tool execution (12), model detection (4), execute_with_tools (5), auto-detection (3), integration (3), backwards compat (3), error handling (3). Coverage requirements: 90% for tools.py, 85% for openrouter.py changes.
Implementing directly - already running as Claude Code in this session. Changes are focused on provider module with good test coverage needed.

Created src/providers/tools.py with 3 tools (read_file, list_files, search_code) and execution functions. Updated src/providers/openrouter.py with: execute_with_tools(), _supports_function_calling(), _execute_basic(), auto-detection in execute(). Path sandboxing implemented. Soft warnings at 2MB/50 calls, hard limit at 200 calls.

details.notes: All 165 tests passing: 50 new tests for function calling + 115 existing tests. Fixed 1 flaky test.

Security review passed. Verified: (1) Path traversal protection via _validate_path() using is_relative_to(), (2) 50MB file size hard limit, (3) Binary file detection, (4) PermissionError handling, (5) No shell execution - read-only tools only, (6) Tool call limits (200 hard cap). No OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities detected. All file paths sandboxed to working_dir.

Architecture review passed. (1) Clean separation: tools.py contains tool logic, openrouter.py contains API integration, (2) No circular dependencies, (3) Consistent interface: all tools return dict with 'content'/'files'/'matches' or 'error', (4) Extensible: new tools can be added to get_tool_definitions(), (5) Backwards compatible: execute() signature unchanged, (6) Follows existing provider pattern with auto-detection and fallback.

Quality review passed. (1) All functions have docstrings with Args/Returns, (2) Consistent logging using logger module, (3) Comprehensive error handling with descriptive messages, (4) Type hints throughout (Path, Optional, dict[str, Any]), (5) 50 tests with 100% coverage on critical paths, (6) No code smells detected, (7) Constants defined at module level for easy configuration.

details.reason: Isolated change - new module added without touching existing code beyond minimal integration in openrouter.py. No refactoring needed.

details.notes: Feature request, not bug fix. Root cause: API-based models (via Claude Code Web) lacked interactive repo context access compared to CLI tools. Solution: Function calling enables models to request files on-demand during execution.

Added learnings section to LEARNINGS.md covering: function calling implementation, path sandboxing pattern, model detection with prefix matching, clarifying questions workflow improvement. Also added Codex models to function calling list and linked to CORE-017 for model updates.
Added CORE-018 for dynamic function calling detection. Updated CORE-017 with auto-update tasks.
Clarifying questions improvement already backported to workflow.yaml

message: Started workflow: Implement multi-source secrets manager that supports env vars, SOPS, and GitHub private repos

details.notes: Reviewed ROADMAP.md - found WF-002 (Available Secrets Documentation) which aligns with this work. Also found checkpoint encryption roadmap item using age (consistent with SOPS).

Questions already resolved in discussion:
1. Priority order: env → SOPS → GitHub repo (first available wins)
2. Config location: workflow.yaml secrets section + orchestrator config for user-specific settings
3. GitHub repo format: Simple files (OPENROUTER_API_KEY, etc.) in private repo
4. SOPS integration: Use existing .manus/secrets.enc.yaml pattern, requires SOPS_AGE_KEY
5. Backwards compatibility: All existing env var usage continues to work
Created docs/plan.md with detailed implementation plan covering SecretsManager class, SOPS integration, GitHub repo integration, CLI commands, and integration points.

Created docs/risk_analysis.md covering 6 risks: secret exposure in logs, GitHub misconfiguration, SOPS failures, cache persistence, breaking existing behavior, and API rate limits. All LOW to MEDIUM severity with clear mitigations.

Created tests/test_cases.md with 30 test cases covering: SecretsManager core (6), SOPS integration (5), GitHub integration (6), CLI commands (8), security (3), integration (3), backwards compatibility (2).
Implementing directly - in Claude Code Web environment where orchestrator handoff is not applicable.
Created src/secrets.py with SecretsManager class supporting env vars, SOPS, and GitHub private repos. Added CLI commands: config (set/get/list) and secrets (test/source/sources).

details.notes: Problem: Claude Code Web can't persist env vars across sessions, making multi-model reviews unusable. Root cause: Ephemeral container design. Solution: Multi-source secrets with GitHub private repo fallback for web environment.

Key learnings documented in LEARNINGS.md:
1. Multi-source secrets pattern enables environment-agnostic secret access
2. Priority ordering (env > SOPS > GitHub) preserves backwards compatibility
3. Memory-only caching prevents secret persistence exposure
4. GitHub private repo provides zero-pasting solution for Claude Code Web

details.reason: WF-002 (Available Secrets Documentation) already exists and is addressed by this implementation
New feature - no backporting applicable
Documentation already updated in CLAUDE.md and SETUP_GUIDE.md

message: Started workflow: Review and finalize secrets management implementation

details.notes: Review is for existing secrets implementation - no roadmap items to check

details.reason: This is a code review task - requirements are clear

details.notes: Review plan: 1) Security audit, 2) Multi-user readiness, 3) UX assessment, 4) Code quality. Security fixes already applied.

Risks identified: 1) Password still required each session (UX friction), 2) Per-repo secrets file (cross-repo friction), 3) Single password = all users share secrets. Mitigations: SOPS for multi-user, docs for cross-repo copy.
Test cases: 31 unit tests already passing. Manual tests: encryption/decryption via stdin works, password not visible in ps.

details.reason: Requirements clear from discussion: Add Aider as invisible review provider for Gemini with full repo context. No open questions.

details.notes: Created implementation plan in docs/plan.md covering: AiderExecutor class, router integration, setup checks, and user experience. Key approach: Use aider --message for non-interactive reviews with full repo context.
Created risk analysis in docs/risk_analysis.md. Overall risk: LOW. Key mitigations: graceful fallback to OpenRouter API, timeout handling, --no-auto-commits and --no-git flags for safety.

Created 10 test cases in tests/test_cases.md covering: AiderExecutor (success, timeout, not found, parsing), ReviewSetup (aider detection), ReviewRouter (routing, fallback, status), and end-to-end integration.

Reviewed new code for security: 1) copy_secrets_file uses Path.resolve() for path normalization - prevents path traversal. 2) API keys are not logged or cached inappropriately. 3) No new external input validation issues. 4) Model registry only stores public model metadata, no secrets.

Architecture follows existing patterns: 1) model_registry.py is a new module with singleton pattern like secrets.py. 2) Environment detection additions follow existing structure. 3) Provider additions follow existing registry pattern. 4) CLI commands follow existing argparse pattern. 5) All additions are additive and backward compatible.

Code quality review: 1) All functions have docstrings with Args/Returns. 2) Type hints used throughout. 3) Comprehensive error handling with logging. 4) Tests cover happy paths and error cases. 5) No code duplication detected. 6) Constants defined at module level.

details.notes: Feature implementation - success factors: 1) Well-specified roadmap items with clear tasks. 2) Existing code patterns to follow. 3) TDD approach (tests first). 4) Incremental implementation.

Learnings: 1) Creating test files that skip when module not implemented enables TDD. 2) Model registry should be updated separately from provider logic. 3) Singleton pattern with optional working_dir parameter provides flexibility. 4) Path.resolve() is essential for copy operations.
